Con el apoyo del prstamo Doa Sandra podr sacar unos pedidos que tiene pendientes de entrega y eso le generara ganancias para cubrir algunos gastos del hogar como ser el pago de alquiler.
Su sueo es tener una casa propia y que sea muy grande porque quiere instalar un pequeo taller y ensear a las personas a elaborar rosquillas y quesadillas.
Doa Sandra se siente muy agradecida por el apoyo de los prestamos obtenidos porque le han ayudado a mantenerse activa econmicamente. Ella es una clienta muy puntual con sus pagos y ya tiene cuatro ciclos en FAMA.
texts.en:
Sandra Margarita is 58, married, and the mother of four children. She lives in Barrio La Hoya in the Juticalpa municipality, and sells rosquillas (a traditional treat similar to doughnuts) and quesadillas.
Sandra learned to make rosquillas and quesadillas more than 30 years ago. She trained by working with a neighbor who did this for a living. Her products are a great favorite of the residents of Juticalpa, and also of people who live in other countries; since the greatest amount of her production is bought to be sent to family members and friends who live in the United States.
She works together with her youngest son. Her working day begins at 4:00am, which is very demanding. But once the product leaves the oven, she can rest, and her son sends it out to the customers.
The loan that Sandra is applying for is needed to buy milk, corn, sugar, firewood, eggs, and other products for making rosquillas and quesadillas. With the help of the loan Sandra, will be able to fill some orders that she hasn't yet delivered, and that will generate profits to cover some household expenses such as rent.
Her dream is to have her own house; a very large one, because she wants to set up a small work area and teach people to make rosquillas and quesadillas.
Sandra feels very thankful for the loan support she has received, because this has helped her keep herself going financially. She is a client who is very punctual with her payments, and has already had four loans with FAMA.

loan.use: To buy corn, sugar, firewood, eggs, etc.

loan.name: Teryleny

texts.en:
Teryleny, age 47, lives in a small home with her husband and one infant daughter. Teryleny has a food-production business where she makes balut (boiled, fertilized eggs) to sell in the community. She has worked all her life to get her family ahead and provide their daily bread. Teryleny is a hard-working woman who gets up every day very early in the morning to get her various dishes ready.
For Teryleny, the most important thing is for her family and customers to be satisfied. She does everything within her power to offer her customers the best, since her dream is to be able to see her business flourish so that people like it more and more every day and eat her rich food.
She has decided to take out this loan to purchase the necessary ingredients and eggs for making new and rich dishes. Her goal is to provoke greater demand for her food and to be able to offer her family a better quality of life.

loan.use: to buy eggs and ingredients for her business.

loan.name: Musharaf's Group

texts.en:
Musharaf is a caring lady who performs her household responsibilities by staying at home. In her spare time, she also supports her husband in managing his business, which is about selling milk.
She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husbands business. With the loan, her husband will buy another buffalo that will allow him to get a larger quantity of milk and increase his sales and profits.
He has been operating his business for the past eight years and Musharaf is hopeful that an investment will help her husband get more profits and increase his client base.

loan.use: To buy another buffalo for the dairy business.

loan.name: Bornice

texts.en:
Bornice is a mother of four aged between 19 and 14 years and all schooling. She is aged 43 and has been in dairy farming for the last 13 years in her home area in Litein, South Rift, Kenya. Her milk produce is sold locally. She currently employs one farmhand.
Bornice has made a first loan request with Juhudi Kilimo amounting to 60,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow at 30,000 KES and a chuff cutter at 30,000 KES, too. She expects her milk output to improve with the additional dairy cow and better feeding as a result of the availability of a chuff cutter.
She notes fluctuation in milk prices as the challenge.

loan.use: To construct a modern dairy unit and buy a chuff cutter (for cutting fodder).

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase tomatoes, onions, cabbages, and bananas for her store

loan.name: Oltiboi

texts.en: Oltiboi is married and is a father of a child. He is a hardworking, smart and goal oriented man. Oltiboi is a farmer. He owns a large plot of land (~60 acres) and grows sunflower seeds, vegetables and wheat there. He also has apricot, plum and quince orchards. For more then 8 years Oltiboi has been running his produce farm and he has a lot of experience in agriculture. Oltiboi is planning to use this loan to purchase more seeds and fertilizer to improve his soil.

loan.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer

loan.name: Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Fatima is the treasurer of this group. She is 40 and unfortunately she is a widow. She has a daughter and a son; her daughter studies at school and her son is preschool age (under seven). Fatima works as a bookkeeper in the Department of Agriculture.
Eight years ago she saved 10,000 soms from her salary and purchased a calf for breeding. Since that time she has been breeding cattle to make additional money. She sells milk products, and in this way earns an additional 1500 soms per month. With money received from the loan Fatima will purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future she plans to start building a shed to keep cattle.
---Where Did This Loan Come From?---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan.
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom linePeople (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team: Supporters of KyrgyzstanMol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase cattle

loan.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is now 53 years of age and lives with her five children. She is now a widow but she has strong faith and a determination to improve their standard of living and give her children a bright future.
The main source of their income is from farming: they plant rice and vegetables and raise livestock for sale. They have been in this business for almost 18 years and usually earn a profit of only 7,500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) a month. Their profits are utilized for their basic necessities and daily expenses of their children.
They often suffer from financial difficulties due to the high cost of commodities and school fees, but through their patience and hard work, they can afford their basic necessities. She aims to improve her hog-raising business and make it a viable source of income. But due to inadequate capital, she is asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP to buy feed, vitamins, vaccines, and additional piglets to raise. She is hoping that the loan will help a lot to improve the business.

loan.use: to buy feed, vitamins, vaccines and additional piglets to raise

loan.name: Saydburkhon

texts.en: Saydburkhon feeds and grows cattle. He is very smart and hardworking man. He is married and has four children. For more than three years he has been doing this business. Saydburkhon wants to expand his business and maximize his profit. He loves his family and wants to support them in good living conditions. He is asking for a loan to buy cattle with the goal to expand his business. He is thanking all the lenders in advance for the support and encouragement.

loan.use: to buy cattle.

loan.name: Zeinep's Group

texts.en:
Zeinep, the leader of this group, is 40 years old and married to a beekeeper. They are raising two daughters, one of whom is attending school while the other is of preschool age.

Two years ago, with an initial investment of 17500 soms, the family started a beekeeping business, with Zeinep selling honey. Currently earning about 5000 soms per month, she has applied for a loan to help in the purchase of more beehives. In the future with the profits gained from selling honey, Zeinep wishes to start building a house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase beehives to expand the business.

loan.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is aged 48 and has been in farming in her home area in Muranga, Central Kenya for 28 years producing coffee, beans, and bananas for the local community. She is married with five children, three of whom are adults while the other two are of school-going age.
Nancy has made a loan request with Juhudi Kilimo of 30,000 KES to purchase a water pump at 20,000 KES and irrigation pipes at 10,000 KES. This is her first loan with Juhudi Kilimo. She says the availability of a constant water supply will improve her output and her family livelihood.
She says Juhudi Kilimos financial services have made access to finance very simple for farmers.

loan.use: To purchase a water pump and irrigation pipes.

loan.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is married with six children and lives in his own house in Hioma, Uganda. He has had a fishing and carpentry business for eight years. He faces the challenge of a lack of adequate equipment to catch the fish, which affects his business profits.
With the income earned from fishing, Nicholas has been able to pay school fees for his children. His business dream is to buy a fishing boat. Nicholas needs this loan to buy a conoe for fishing.

loan.use: to buy a canoe for fishing.

loan.name: Enma Cristina

texts.es:
Doa Enma tiene 43 aos de edad, es casada y tiene seis hijos, y junto a su familia reside en la Colonia Bella Vista en el municipio de Juticalpa, es una persona muy trabajadora y desde hace varios aos se dedica a la venta de abarrotera.
Doa Enma tiene una pequea pulpera que funciona en su domicilio, con un horario de atencin de 6:00 am 8:00 pm. Inicio simplemente con una venta de refrescos pero las personas que iban a comprarle siempre le preguntaban por productos de la canasta bsica as que solicito un prstamo en FAMA e hizo las gestiones necesarias para instalar la pulpera que ahora tiene. Su principal ventaja es que es una persona muy conocida en la colonia y por eso sus vecinos prefieren realizar sus compras en su pulpera.
El prstamo que Doa Enma solicita lo necesita para surtir su pulperia con la compra de arroz, frijoles, azucar, manteca, pastas, refrescos, carnes, embutidos, lacteos, churros, galletas, confites, entre otros productos de la canasta basica.
Su meta es tener un mercadito y que este le permita obtener mayores ganancias para seguir apoyando a sus hijos con el estudio hasta verlos graduarse en la universidad y tambin desea que su de vida mejore.
texts.en:
Enma is 43 years old, she is married and she has six children. She lives with her family in Bella Vista, a village of the municipality of Juticalpa. She is a very hard working person and she has been engaged in selling groceries for a few years.
Enma runs a small corner shop in her house, working from 6 am to 8 pm. She started with a simple soft drink sales, but as the people who came buying at her stall where asking for basic daily products as well, she decided to ask FAMA for a loan, ad she took the necessary steps to set the corner shop she now owns. Her main advantage is being a well-known person in her village, and for this reason her neighbors prefer to buy their products in her corner shop.
The loan Enma is requesting will be used to buy general merchandise in order to supply her shop with rice, beans, sugar, butter, pasta, soft drinks, meat, sausage, dairy products, fritters, cookies, and sweets, among other basic products.
She aims at running a business that, by generating more earnings will help her keep on supporting her children with their studies, up to see them graduating at university; she also wants her life to improve.

loan.use: to buy rice, beans, sugar, butter, pasta, soft drinks, and meat.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to buy maize and beans to sell.

loan.name: Abduvoris

texts.en: Abduvoris is married and is a loving father of four children. He grows agriculture crops. He mainly grows onion and melons. He has been in this business for more than seven years and continues to have success. Abduvoris wants to get a loan to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds. He wants to expand his business so that he can support his family in good living conditions.

loan.use: to buy mineral fertilizer and seeds.

loan.name: Nobert

texts.en:
Nobert is aged 41 and has been in farming for 7 years, producing and selling milk, maize and beans for the local market. He is married with five children aged between 14 and 1 year old with the first 4 already schooling.
Nobert has requested a loan of 41,600 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says this will improve his milk production and give additional supplement for the family meals and income. He is focusing on owning six dairy cows and a cereal-grinding machine in the local market.
High cost of animal feed stands out as the major challenge in farming. He intends to repay the loan and acquire another one.

loan.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loan.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia is married and her husband has a business of selling hosiery. He sells socks and panties to different garments shops of the market and earns income. He has been in this profession for many years and his customers have good level of trust in him due to his good quality work.
Safia is a housewife who stays at her home and does her household responsibilities. She has three sons, all of whom are young and support their father in his business.
Safia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husbands business. With the loan, he will buy hosiery items in bulk to be able to fulfill his clients' demand and increase his profits.
Safia is very confident that her husbands business will grow and she will be able to pay for the wedding of her eldest son, who is now 26 years old.
Note: In the photo, Safia is raising her hand.

loan.use: To buy hosiery (socks and panties) items for selling.

loan.name: Yaser

texts.en:
Yaser, a 27-year-old married father of a son and a daughter, lives in Irtah village near the city of Tulkarem in Palestine. Yaser earns income from agriculture but also owns and operates a taxi.

Yaser wants to make some improvements to the taxi including regular maintenance, painting, new tires, etc. and so is requesting a loan of $3,000 from FATEN. The loan, which will be repaid on a monthly basis, will lead to a more efficient taxi service, and he will work extra hours to increase his income and provide better living conditions for his family.

loan.use: to pay for repairs to the taxi .

loan.name: Emommakhmad

texts.en: Emommakhmad is married and has five children. He is involved in buying and selling vegetables at the local central market. He has been selling at the market for over 15 years and has very good experience. Emommakhmad primarily sells onions, potatoes, carrots and beats. He wants to expand his business and improve his quality of life. He is requesting this loan in the sum of $1000 for the purchase of vegetables in order to expand his business.

loan.use: to purchase vegetables

loan.name: Arturo

texts.en:
Arturo is a father who has worked hard to give his four children a better life and an improved standard of living. As the fruit of his patience and sacrifices, most of their children have finished their studies and found good jobs. Now 49 years old, Arturo and his family live happily in a rural community, planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been in this business for almost 33 years and usually earns a profit of P30,000 every harvest season.

At present, Arturo aims to increase their yields and income to satisfy their needs and save for future emergencies. He is requesting a loan of P30,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for an improved upcoming harvest, and to pay the labor costs involved in planting rice. Arturo hopes that in the future, he will improve the business and become financially stable.

loan.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides and to pay labor costs involved in planting rice.

loan.name: Lorna

texts.en:
This is Lorna, 41, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Arbi, a mechanic, and mother to their four children. Three are already in college while the youngest is still in high school. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
Lorna operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this she also offers direct selling products to her customers. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She takes in a minimum of Php 5000 in sales every day.
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 30,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Lorna hopes her business grows more in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loan.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick successfully paid back his previous loan in full, four months ahead of schedule. He's been approved for a larger loan of 40,000 KES to continue growing his business. With this loan, Patrick intends to purchase more spare parts to sell in his bicycle shop.

loan.use: to purchase more spare parts to sell in his bicycle shop

loan.name: Edalyn

texts.en:
Edalyn is 31 years old and single. She works hard running a sari-sari (variety) store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional items to sell.
Edalyn has borrowed and repaid four loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for four years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice.
Edalyn aspires to save money to expand her business.

loan.use: To purchase additional items to sell.

loan.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is age 36. She is a farmer in the Nkubu area of Central Kenya with her farm producing potatoes and cabbages for the local market. She has been in farming for 10 years. She sells second hand shoes in the local market to generate more income. She is married with one child who is nine years old.
Lucy has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a water tank. She will use the income generated to educate her child. She aspires to buy a piece of land to construct her own residential house.
She adds that it has been easy dealing with Juhudi Kilimo because of its reliability.

loan.use: To purchase a water tank

loan.name: Mendsuren

texts.en:
Mendsuren is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three children who are between 10 and 15 years old. They live in a small house located in a local ger district (a district without basic infrastructure) in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her children attend public school. Her husband works as a top sergeant of a squad of soldiers.
Mendsuren has supported her family by operating two clothing retail stalls at the largest outdoor market in Mongolia for nine years. She has been successfully expanding her business and has been able to improve her living conditions. She bought a car for her husband in 2008 and built her small house in 2009 with her business earnings.
Today, she wants to improve her business very well in order to buy one more stall at her present market and to import clothes to sell from Ereen, a border city between Mongolia and China. For this reason, Mendsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT (/Mongolian Tugriks) loan from Kiva lenders to purchase clothes for fall and to buy one stall.

loan.use: to purchase clothes and to buy one more stall

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To maintain his car and purchase two pigs

loan.name: Eleuteria

texts.en:
This is Eleuteria, 52, a resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Gabriel, an electronics technician. She is also mother to their three children. Two of her children are already working, while the youngest is still in high school. Eleuteria and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
Eleuteria operates a business renting gowns and shoes. She buys second-hand gowns and shoes, and then offers them to others who would like to rent them on a daily basis. These gowns are used for special occasions and other formal gatherings. She also sells accessories for additional income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and others in the local community. She earns a minimum of 320 PHP in sales every day.
To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a loan for 8,000 PHP. She will be utilizing the loan to buy additional gowns and shoes to expand her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Eleuteria hopes her business grows more in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week. She also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro finance loans.

loan.use: To buy additional gowns and shoes

loan.name: Christy

texts.en:
Christy is 25 years old and married with one child.
Christy works hard to provide for her family. She runs a sari-sari (convenience) store in the Philippines. She has been running the sari-sari store for five years and also earns an income from raising pigs.
She requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell like toothpaste and groceries. Christy has borrowed and paid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan.
Christy aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loan.use: To purchase items to sell

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to pay for purchasing agriculture tools and supplies.

loan.name: George

texts.en:
George is a farmer in Nkubu area. He is age 50 and has been farming for eight years. His farm produces carrots, cabbages and potatoes. He works as a plumber for additional income besides farming. He says high costs of farm inputs limit many farmers' farming income significantly.
George has made a loan request for 40,000 Kenyan shillings from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase water pipes for an irrigation system. He says the irrigation system will make his production consistent and generate enough income to meet his family's needs. He wants to buy more land, too, from the income.

loan.use: to purchase irrigation pipes.

loan.name: Samina's Group

texts.en:
Samina has given birth to 4 children, all of whom are enrolled in a local school and are getting an education. She helps to support her family by operating a sewing business. She learned this art from her mother before marrying, and is now fully skilled in her work. She receives regular orders, which help her to earn a good income every month.
Saminas husband operates a business selling crushed wood. This wood is used to make furniture like cupboards, tables etc. He has vast experience in his field and makes good sales every month. Samina has applied for a loan for her husbands business from Kiva partner Asasah. With this loan, he will buy crushed wood in bulk that will allow him to fulfill client orders on time and increase his profits. Samina is confident that this investment will help her husband get better results from his business and improve her familys standard of living as a result.

loan.use: To buy crushed wood in bulk

loan.name: Lawrence

texts.en: Lawrence is 29 years old, married, and has a 9-month-old child. He rents a house in Hioma, Uganda. He has been running a retail shop for 3 years, and he faces a challenge of price fluctuations, which affect his business profits. He needs this loan to buy sugar, soap and matchboxes to sell. He hopes to expand his business into a wholesale shop in the next five years.

loan.use: to buy sugar, soap and matchboxes to sell

loan.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida is a twenty-nine-year-old from Kakamega. She is married to Victor and they have three children.
Vida has a secretarial bureau that she has been running for the past four years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD to enable her to buy computer accessories to add to her stock.
She hopes to see her business expand and open another bureau in the neighboring town in the future.

loan.use: To buy computer accessories.

loan.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia is a married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. For the past three years she has been in the business of selling food items like avocados and lemons in Hai Gwafa, Yei, South Sudan. She requested this loan through BRAC to enable her purchase more lemons to sell. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to build a house for her children in the future.

loan.use: to enable her purchase more lemons to sell

loan.name: Ashurali

texts.en: Ashurali is involved in buying and selling food products. He is married and has tow children. He is a goal-oriented and hard-working person. Ashurali sells everyday products, such as bread, cookies, candy and others. He is the owner of this business and has a very good experience. He has been running this business for over six years. Ashurali wants to obtain a loan for the purchase of a new assortment of products in order to expand his business.

loan.use: to buy food products

loan.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is 32 years old, married to Julius. They live in Kakamega town and have three children.
Teresa has a call center where she sells calling cards as well as offers money transactions. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD to enable her to increase her e-float (stored-value credits for sale in mobile money service)
She hopes to expand her business to open another call center in the neigbouring town in the future.

loan.use: To buy e-float (stored-value credits for sale in mobile money service)

loan.name: Suiumbubu's Group

texts.en:
Suiumbubu is the leader of this group. She is 63 and, unfortunately, a widow. She has a 21 year old son, who earns money by working as a driver. He also helps his mother to run her cattle breeding business. Suiumbubu has a lot of experience in this area; she started breeding cattle 43 years ago. She plans to use her loan to purchase cattle feed. In the future she wants to see her son get married.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (staying environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team (Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance) at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase cattle feed

loan.name: Michelle

texts.en:
Michelle is from the rural area of Bolinao province of Isabela. She is 29-years-old with four children. She is a vendor of eggs in their community. She is a very loving and understanding mother. She does everything she can just to support the daily needs of her family. Her spouse is a farmer.
Michelle is asking for a loan of P 5,000 to buy new eggs for additional income for her business. She hopes that in the future her that business will expand and improve.

loan.use: to buy eggs for her business.

loan.name: Samwel

texts.en:
Samwel is a farmer in the Nkubu area of central Kenya. He is 61 years of age and married with seven children, all of whom are adults. He has been in farming for the last 30 years producing bananas, maize, beans, coffee and milk and selling to the local market. He also works with the P.C.E.A church, which provides additional income.
Samwel has requested a loan of 63,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says he will use the income from farming to purchase a extra parcel of land to expand his farming by introducing both pigs and dairy goats to his farm.
He says they face challenges as a result of pests and diseases, but he remains optimistic and appreciative of Juhudi Kilimo for their support of farmers.

loan.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow

loan.name: Arsenio

texts.en:
Arsenio is 49-years-old, married and has three school-age children. His goal is to improve his hog-raising business to support his family and continue sending his children to school. He has been in this business for almost 28 years earning profits of P10,000 a month that he uses for their basic necessities and to finance the education of their children. Despite the hardships and difficulties of life, he has the strong determination to uplift their status of living and to give his children a better life.
His goal is to raise more pigs to increase his income. He is asking for a loan of P35,000 to buy feed, vitamins and vaccines for his hog-raising business. He believes that this loan will contribute a lot to make the business grow and become a viable source of income.

loan.use: to buy feed, vitamins and vaccines for a hog-raising business.

loan.name: Alex

texts.en: Alex is 24-years-old and married with a child aged 11-months old. He lives in his own house in Hioma, Uganda. He has been dealing in a cosmetics business for 2 years and he faces challenges of price fluctuations and lack of adequate capital to meet the increasing demand. His dream is to upgrade his retail shop to a whole sale shop. Alex wants the loan to buy cosmetics for sale.

loan.use: to buy cosmetics for sale.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase more groceries for sale.

loan.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is a married woman with six children, one of whom is in school. Cecilia has a business of selling clothes in Hai gwafa branch in Yei South Sudan She has been in this business for four years.
Cecilia requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She says that with the extra income from this loan she will use it for building a house for her children in future.

loan.use: to purchase more clothes for sale.

loan.name: Batma's Group

texts.en:
Batma, the leader of this group, is 31, married to a constructor, and the mother of a daughter and three sons. The daughter and the older son attend school, while the other two sons are of preschool age.

Batma breeds livestock and cultivates agricultural products, selling some part of the harvest and livestock when they need money. At the moment Batma wants to increase her number of livestock and so is requesting a loan to purchase four to five farm animals for breeding. In the near future she wants to purchase home furniture to improve the familys living conditions.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase livestock.

loan.name: Verekano

texts.en: Verekano, a married father of six children who lives in his own house in Hoima, Uganda, has been fishing for 10 years, a livelihood that has enabled him to provide the basics for his family. Now requesting a loan to purchase a boat, he faces the challenge of fish depletion due to government negligence in enforcing its fishing policy. Verekano's dream is to acquire a fishing tender at the shore and buy two more boats.

loan.use: to buy a boat.

loan.name: Shaymaa

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. She is 28 years old, married and lives with her husband and two children.
Shaymaa has been an owner of a women's beauty salon since 2010, offering hairdressing, makeup, manicures and pedicure. She has good experience in this field, a deep understanding of the local customers, and knows about their needs. She has a good reputation and she is well known in the surrounding areas.
She decided to apply for a $1,800 loan in order to redecorate, paint and renovate her shop. She is aiming to gain more profits to offer her the opportunity to provide a better life for her family as a whole.

loan.use: to redecorate, paint and renovate her shop.

loan.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian, a married woman with five children, all of whom are in school, has had a business for the past three years selling beans and cooking oil in Hai Gwafa, located in Yei, South Sudan. She has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan in the hopes of expanding her business. Vivian says that the extra income resulting from this loan will help her to build a store for her business expansion.

loan.use: to purchase more beans and cooking oil to sell.

loan.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is a 43-year-old married man with 10 children living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family rests on him and his dream is to educate his children up to the university level.
Moses owns a bar and he has operated it for the last five years. His hardship is price flactuation and his dream is to have a big bar and hotel. Moses needs a loan to buy crates of beer for resale.

loan.use: To buy crates of beer for resale.

loan.name: Julita

texts.en:
This is Julita, age 53, a resident of GMA, Cavite City, Philippines. She is single and manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.
Julita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 Philippines pesos (PHP) worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by purchasing supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this, Julita also earns extra income from the apartment rentals that she operates. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 480 in sales every day.
To help her continue operations of her business, she requests a PHP 15,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.
Julita hopes to grow her business more in the coming years and to help her family members who are in need. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loan.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loan.name: Shaarkan's Group

texts.en:
Shaarkan is the leader of this group. She is 63, and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised a son, age 22, who works as a policeman.
In 1999 with an initial investment of 10,000 Kyrgyzstan soms (KGS), Shaarkan started to sell shoes. She now runs a grocery store, in order to earn money to meet her family's needs. She applies for this loan because she needs additional money to purchase more products to increase her product sales. She will purchase beverages, cookies, candies, and other supplies. In the future, Shaarkan plans to expand the store.
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loan.use: to purchase products to sell.

loan.name: Maate

texts.en: Maate is a 45-year-old married man with two children. He lives in his own house in Fort Portal Uganda. Maate deals in selling dry foods, a business he has operated for 20 years. With the income earned, he has been able to build a residential house. His major problem has been price fluctuations and his dream is setting up a food store. Maate needs a loan to pay school fees for his children.

loan.use: To pay school fees for his children.

loan.name: Zarina Mai's Group

texts.en:
Zarina mai is a caring lady who carries out her responsibilities as a housewife by staying at home. She makes the utmost effort to provide comfort to her family by fulfilling their needs.
Zarina mai's husband operates a soft drink corner in the market, where he serves many customers. His sales improve in the summer season. He has been in this business for many years. He serves his customers chilled drinks like Coca-Cola, Pepsi, and fruit-flavored juices.
Zarina mai has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husbands business. With this loan, he will buy cold drinks and juices in larger quantity that will allow him to make good sales and increase his profits.
Zarina mai is hopeful that an investment will bring better profits to her husband.
Note: In the photo, the other member is showing her sewing work.

loan.use: To buy cold drinks and juices for her husband's soft drink corner.

loan.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married with seven children, all of whom go to school. She has additional family members. She operates a pub from home retail basis, working six days a week. She has been in business for the last 30 years.
Deborah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Uganda shillings (UGX) from MCDT SACCO to buy more crates of beer and soda, and jerrycans of local gin. Her major challenge includes transportation and electricity.
Deborah aspires to educate her children to university level and also to own a fully stocked pub. She lives in a rented house and her family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, paying utility bills, and rent.

loan.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda, and jerrycans of local gin.

loan.name: Shareefa

texts.en:
Shareefa is a 51-year-old woman. She is married and has four sons and two daughters. Some of her sons are a construction workers with decent salaries.
Shareefa has a store for selling DVDs and computers. She wants to purchase more computers to sell because of high demand from customers. She has some money, but not enough to pay for the additional inventory, so she needs to take a loan in the amount of $1,000 from FATEN to complete the amount she needs to pay. When Shareefa gets this loan that is to be repaid on a monthly basis, she will be able to pay for purchasing more computers to sell, which will enable her to increase her income and offer better living conditions for her family.
Shareefa is a conservative woman, so her son Mahmoud is photographed instead in the store.

loan.use: To purchase computers for sale.

loan.name: Kidubuli Banana Famers S &c Group

texts.en: Rose is a 48-year-old married woman with six children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She operates a retail shop dealing in general merchandise such as soap, sugar, and other items. Her major problem has been price fluctuations of products. Rose's dream is to have a wholesale shop and to educate her children. Rose needs the loan to buy soap and sugar for resale.

loan.use: To buy general merchandise for resale.

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: to purchase feed, vitamins, and vaccines for her hog-raising business.

loan.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a married lady with four children for whom she hopes to provide a good education to the university level.
Rose runs a a photocopying services business situated at a hall in the University of Nairobi, where she provides photocopying services to the university students. She says the business is good, but she experiences low business seasons when the campus students leave for vacation. She also owns a beauty salon business, which adds to her income from the photocopying business.
She will use her loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings (KES) to buy salon equipment to grow her salon business, which has a lot of potential, as well as to get ready as we near Christmas, when most customers will need the beauty services. She describes herself as humble and joyful.

loan.use: To buy salon equipment.

loan.name: Yunice

texts.en:
Yunice is a married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. She has a business of selling breads in Hai Gwafa branch in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.
Yunice requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to able her purchase more breads for sale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to pay for her children to go to school.

loan.use: she want more income to able her purchase more breads for sale.

loan.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is a married man with one school-going child. He has a house with electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are for his family and school fees.
He has operated a pharmacy for the past three years; in addition, his wife also contributes in the family expenses. His potential clients are his local area neighbors. His major challenge is finding customers for his business. He dreams of establishing a wholesale pharmacy in the future.
With the 20,000 Kenya shilling (KES) loan, he wants to purchase drugs for his pharmacy. He decided to join Yehu because of low loan repayments rate.

loan.use: To purchase drugs for his pharmacy.

loan.name: Sultonchon

texts.en: Sultonchon lives in the Bohtar district. He is 25 years old, married and has one child. He has a secondary education. He is involved in sales and has a store in the town of Sarband. Sultonchon primarily sells food products and perfumery products. He has been involved in this business for two years. He is requesting this loan for the purchase of perfumery products, flour, sugar, carbonated drinks and a refrigerator.

loan.use: to purchase perfumery products, flour, sugar, carbonated drinks and a refrigerator

loan.name: Tsatsral

texts.en:
Tsatsral is a 27-year-old young lady entrepreneur who has two children, who are two and four years old. Both of them attend kindergarten. Her family lives in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, which is located in the outer ger district (a district without basic infrastructure) of Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia.
Tsatsral has been supporting her family by operating a clothing retail stall at the largest outdoor market of Mongolia, for six years, with the help of her spouse. She usually sells women's clothes, which she imports from Ereen, a border city between Mongolia and China. As she is a friendly person, she has already had her own constant customers.
Tsatsral wants to expand her business in order to increase her working capital. So she is requesting a 2,000,000 MNT (Mongolian Tugriks) loan to purchase clothes from Ereen city to sell for this high shopping season. Her long-term goal is to improve her living conditions by renovating her current small house.

loan.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loan.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a forty-three-year-old married man with four children and he owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family rests on him and his dream is to educate his children up to university. He has been in farming and also trading in agricultural produce for thirty years. His hardship is drought and his vision is bigger farm yields, acquiring land, plus setting up a food store.
Benard needs the loan to buy fertilizers for his banana plantation.

loan.use: to buy fertilizers for his banana plantation

loan.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is taking out another Kiva loan of 40,000 KES. With the loan she is taking, she wants to venture into another business of making fruit juice for sale. She wants to purchase sacks of fruits for the juice making business. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers needs and improve her living standards.

loan.use: To purchase sacks of fruits for making fruit juices for sale.

loan.name: Aysha

texts.en:
Aysha is a 50-year-old woman. She is married and has four sons and three daughters. Some of her sons are Palestinian National Authority employees with decent salaries.
Aysha lives in Dier Sharaf village near Nablus city in Palestine. She has a canteen to serve the university students. She wants to purchase greater varieties for sale but the amount of money she has isn't enough to pay, so she needs to take a loan of $1,000 from FATEN.
When Aysha gets the loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, she will pay to purchase the variety she needs for the canteen to sell to university students. She will have a wider range of items for sale and increase her income and provide better living conditions for her family. Aysha is a conservative woman, so her son is photographed instead of her.

loan.use: To increase the range of goods she sells in the university canteen.

loan.name: Nathaniel

texts.en:
Nathaniel is a married man with two children, one of whom is attending school and the other is too young for school. He has a house with electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family.
For the past three years, he has operated a green grocery business. His wife also contributes in covering the family expenses. He faces a major challenge of transportation. His potential clients are local area neighbors. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.
With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase vegetables for his business. He decided to join Yehu for easy access of loans to expand his business.

loan.use: To purchase vegetables for his business.

loan.name: Marter

texts.en:
Marter is a married woman with four children, three of whom are in school. She has a business selling bread and onions in Hai Gwafa in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.
Marter requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to pay for her children to go to school

loan.use: to purchase more bread and onions for sale.

loan.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is a married lady in Kenya. She has four children who she hopes to be able to provide a university-level education. She owns a business making jewelry at Dandora in Nairobi. She has been doing this business for the last nine years. She says that the business is profitable and her biggest challenge is financial constraints. She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy beads for making bracelets and necklaces in order to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. In the future, she plans to grow her business into wholesale. She describes herself as a very honest lady.

loan.use: To buy beads

loan.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en: Mwanajuma has fully repaid her first Kiva loan and she is taking another larger loan of 20,000 KES. With the loan, she intends to add inventory to her business by purchasing three bags of cashew nuts for resale. She dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier of cashew nuts in the future.

loan.use: To purchase sacks of cashew nuts for sale

loan.name: John

texts.en: John is a 40-year-old married man with four children living in a permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. The responsibility of looking after the family rests on him, and his desire is to educate his children up to the university level. He is a farmer who grows vegetables to earn a living; he has been doing this for the last 15 years. His challenge is seasonal changes. His dream is to practice mechanised farming. John needs the loan to pay school fees for his children.

loan.use: To pay school fees for his children

loan.name: Eshrat's Group

texts.en:
Eshrat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who is a painter by profession. He paints walls, buildings and houses on order. He makes contracts with the owners and earns on daily basis while the contract is valid.
With this loan, Eshrat's husband will buy paint brushes and different paint boxes to provide better quality paint services to his clients and increase his profits. He is well-experienced in his business and Eshrat hopes that this investment will be a productive one for his business and helps him improve the living standard of the family.
Eshrat is the mother of 4 children. All of them are very young and havent started their education yet. She is a regular loan user of Asasah's and this is her 2nd loan application. In the previous loan year, she had established good credit behavior and never missed any meeting.
Note: In the photo, the lady with a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Eshrat.

loan.use: To buy brushes and paint for painting business

loan.name: Angus

texts.en:
Angus is a married man with four school-going children. He has a house with electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expense is food for his family.
He has been operating a public addressing system for hire business for the past five years. His wife also contributes toward the family expenses. He faces a major challenge in transportation. His potential clients are the local area residents. He dreams of expanding his business in the future.
With this loan for Kshs 20,000, Angus wants to purchase amplifiers and guitars for his business. He decided to join Yehu for easy access to loans to expand his business.

loan.use: To purchase amplifiers and guitars for his business

loan.name: Khudaynazar

texts.en: Khudaynazar lives in the J. Rumy district. He is 51 years old, married and has three children. His children are in the Russian Federation. Khudaynazar provides a taxi service. He transports people from one place to another. He has been involved in this business for eight years. He is requesting this loan to make repairs to his car.

loan.use: to make repairs to his car

loan.name: Amal

texts.en:
Amal is a 39-year-old woman. She is married and has four sons. Her husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a small salary.
Amal wants to purchase new home appliances she needs to improve her daily life, such as: refrigerator, washing machine, stove, etc. but she hasn't enough money to pay for them because of the small salary her husband gets. So she needs to take out a loan in the amount $1,500 from FATEN. When Amal takes this loan, which is repaid on a monthly basis, she will be able to purchase the basic home appliances she needs to improve her daily life and offer better living conditions to her family.
Amal is a conservative woman, so her husband is photographed instead at the FATEN branch.

loan.use: purchase new home appliances

loan.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma is a single woman with no children. She has a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for herself and transport.
She has been operating a clothes selling business for the past year. In addition, she also sells groceries. Her potential clients are the neighboring community members. She faces a major challenge in transportation. She dreams of establishing a bigger shop in the future.
With this loan for Kshs 20,000, Emma wants to purchase clothes to sell in her business. She decided to join Yehu because of the easy accessibility of loan facilities.

loan.use: buy clothes to sell

loan.name: Evalin

texts.en:
Evalin is a married woman with four children, three of whom are in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Hai Gwafa in Yei county, South Sudan.she has been in this business for three years.
Evalin requested this loan through BRAC in South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her pay for her children to go to school.

loan.use: buy charcoal

loan.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
Lourdes is 52, married and has three adult children. Her husband is a farmer and they live happily in a village where they plant and harvest rice for sale. Their common goal in life is to become successful so that they can give their children a bright future and help those who are in need of in terms of financial aspects. To achieve their goal they plan to improve their rice farming business by increasing their crop yields in every harvest season.
In this regard, Lourdes wants to ask for an additional capital of P15,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and pay the labor cost required in planting rice. They hope that they can increase their yields and income this coming harvest season.

loan.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, pesticides and pay the labor cost required in planting rice.

loan.name: Zivamutunyo Kyamujanju Group

texts.en: Agatha is a member of Zivamutunyo Kyamujanju Group. She is married with a child aged 8-months and lives in a rented house in Karuguuza, Uganda. She has a retail shop and she has been operating it for 6 months. She started by buying 2 calves, reared them and then sold them to start the retail shop. She faces a challenge of thieves who break into her shop and her dream is wholesale shop. Agatha needs the loan to buy rice, paraffin and tea leaves to sell.

loan.use: to buy general merchandise.

loan.name: Halima

texts.en:
Halima is a single woman with one child who attends school. She lives at a family house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.
For the past two years, she has operated a poultry farming business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of increasing her broilers to make more profits in the future.
With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to pay school fees for her child. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her family living standards.

loan.use: to pay school fees for her child.
